metadata.sermon_title: Trinity Sunday & Second Sunday after Pentecost
metadata.sermon_start_end: Imagine for a moment that you are the parent of a child, or young person, who appears to be on the verge of self-destruction. [...] with him there is plenteous redemption, and he shall redeem Israel from all his iniquities. (130:7–8)

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The text treats two distinct pericopes as separate homiletical reflections rather than a single unified sermon. While it identifies the 'fullness' of the Trinitarian blessing in 2 Cor 13 as unique, it largely uses the texts as springboards for general themes of 'self-giving love' and 'sin as catastrophe.' It fails to identify what is in these specific passages that can be found NOWHERE else in the Bible.
quotes: The one that we read today is the longest, richest, and fullest of all his valedictory blessings.
The depth of which the psalmist is actually speaking here is the depth of the knowledge that he and everyone else is a 'miserable offender.'
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Focus on one pericope. Instead of general definitions of the Trinity or Sin, isolate the specific linguistic 'surprises' of the text—e.g., why 'fear' follows 'forgiveness' in Psalm 130 specifically.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is a basic awareness of the Corinthian crisis and the liturgical history of the Psalm (De Profundis). However, the 'Greek and Hebrew' requirement is absent. The exegesis remains at the level of a literary commentary rather than a rigorous theological-historical exposition.
quotes: The Corinthian church has gone completely off the rails...
One commentator called it almost too painful to read.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Move beyond the 'painful' tone of the letter to the specific theological necessity of the Trinitarian formula in the face of Corinthian factionalism.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application relies heavily on sentimental analogies (the drug-addicted child) and liturgical nostalgia (the 1976 Prayer Book). It lacks the 'broad knowledge of humanities' or 'zeitgeist' analysis Dekker demands. It remains in the realm of 'general truths' about love and sin.
quotes: Imagine for a moment that you are the parent of a child...
The removal of this line has robbed us of a powerful buttress to the biblical concept of sin...
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Replace the generic 'parent-child' analogy with a concrete analysis of how the contemporary 'zeitgeist' rejects the concept of being 'lost' or 'miserable' in specific social or psychological terms.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon follows a pattern of 'Illustration -> Textual Observation -> General Application.' The hearer is not so much 'expounded' by the text as they are invited to compare the text to their own experiences. The movement is parallel rather than integrated.
quotes: Reflect on your own life. Think about those people who have borne with you.
This is the movement of Psalm 130, widely acknowledged to be one of the greatest...
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Avoid starting with 'Imagine...' (anecdote). Start with the text's own movement so the application arises from the exposition's internal logic.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: This is the strongest aspect. The sermon takes 'misery' (miserable offenders) and 'redemption' (plenteous redemption) seriously. It explicitly defends the necessity of acknowledging the 'depths.'
quotes: The depth of which the psalmist is actually speaking here is the depth of the knowledge that he and everyone else is a 'miserable offender.'
This is not self-abasement leading to paralysis; this is honesty leading to deliverance.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Strengthen the 'gratitude' aspect; the sermon ends on 'redemption' but lacks the specific 'gratitude awakened by the Spirit' as a life-shaping response.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon touches on the 'impulse toward self-destruction' and the 'path of life.' It takes the possibility of being 'lost' seriously, which Dekker values, but it frames it more as a psychological/liturgical loss than an ultimate destination.
quotes: The idea that we can add up our virtues... is decisively repudiated.
Not the man who is lost, but the man who is about to be saved can understand that he is a sinner.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Address the 'two ways' more explicitly as a choice regarding man's destination, rather than just a 'shift of mood' in a psalm.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is mentioned as the 'incarnate love' and the 'telos' of the blessing. The sermon correctly identifies that man has no life in himself. However, it borders on 'objective' Christocentrism which Dekker warns against if not balanced by the 'three parts.'
quotes: God’s love spends itself to the very last drop of the blood of the Son.
The love that has become incarnate in history through Jesus Christ...
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Connect Christ's two natures more explicitly to the 'miserable' condition of the hearer to avoid a 'vague, romanticized version of love.'

8_depth_and_length.findings: The estimated duration is roughly 14-15 minutes. According to Dekker, 'a sermon that lasts less than 20 minutes cannot be a sermon.' It lacks the 'breadth' required for true 'depth.'
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: The preacher must expand the theological 'exposition' phase to allow the text to breathe, reaching at least the 20-minute threshold.

overall_assessment.summary: The text falls short of Dekker's definition of a sermon primarily due to its brevity and its fragmented focus on two different liturgical occasions. It relies on sentimental illustrations ('parent-child') rather than rigorous humanities-based application. However, it successfully recovers the 'miserable offender' (misery) aspect of the Heidelberg tradition, which is rare in modern preaching.
strengths: Serious treatment of human misery and the 'primordial catastrophe' of sin.
Rejection of 'petty record keeping' in favor of divine grace.
Clear Trinitarian focus in the first section.
weaknesses: Insufficient length (under 20 minutes) prevents homiletical depth.
Lack of specific exegesis (no Greek/Hebrew or unique textual particularity).
Application is often general or nostalgic rather than concrete and contemporary.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is an 'adequate' liturgical reflection but not yet a 'sermon' by Dekker's standards. It lacks the necessary breadth (length) and the specific, non-transferable textual 'exposition' that distinguishes a sermon from a general religious speech.
